blocks.text: must be spread over five times its usual base; now the mean height of the curve \( c_{s} = 06 \) sin over the period to \( 120 \) is \( 1.53 \times 37.56 \) or 0.076.
Then the mean value of the force is \( C = \frac{3185}{k-200} = 3261.\)
The nature of the average should be clearly understood; for it is possible that the same quantity may have diverse averages according to the way the average is expressed.
Suppose a force is presented by a variable force; then the average value of that force might be found by taking readings at the very next of the stroke and dividing by the number of readings taken.

If one wishes to have the average computed from all measurements taken then, if \( c_{s} \, \) has the average and \( c \, \) its means, then we might take average space which may be termed a space vector.

Suppose a bullet penetrates to a distance \( s = vt \) where \( v \) would be the space average, \( P \) calculated from the formula \( P = \frac{m}{c} \) , \[ t = \frac{m}{e} \] where \( e \) is the force average.

To illustrate further: a body starts from rest and its speed increases at the uniform rate of \( 2 \,\text{m/s}^{2} \). Find the time and space averages of the velocity if the motion is considered to take place over \( 600 \,\text{s}. \)
